{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-050-06-A |Item_parent=Genito-scrotal pathology in boys and men |Item_parent_short=Genito-scrotal pathology in boys and men |Rank=A |Title=Know how to manage orchi-epididymitis |Description=None |Rubric=Management |Contributors=Cédric Lebâcle, Alice Faure |Order=6}}
*If an STI is suspected, either ceftriaxone 500 mg in 1 IM injection, followed by Doxycycline 200mg/d for 10 days, or ofloxacin 200mg twice daily for 10 days. *If it is not a sexually transmitted infection, the antibiotic treatment is that of a male urinary infection targeting enterobacteria and is based on a fluoroquinolone (ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin) or 3rd generation cephalosporin secondarily adapted to the antibiogram. *In children, the first-line antibiotic treatment is cotrimoxazole. *The duration of treatment in adults and children is the same as for male urinary tract infections, 14 days. *Wearing a jockstrap (or tight briefs) and prescribing painkillers are recommended.
